Papinot indicates that prior to the 12th c., the Kokushi lived in the
provi=
nces they governed, and their terms at times varied depending on
the distan=
ce from the capital. After the 12th c., they remained in
Kyoto and were rep=
resented by a Mokudai. By the 14th c., the title was
reserved to the kuge (=
nobles) and passed out of use.

-- 
Craig Harris
Books from and about Asia
=
www.bridgeofdreams.com


On 6/14/05, Haynes, A (Angus) <angus.haynes@raboba=
nk.com> wrote:
> Can anyone shed some light on this role? From what I under=
stand, kokushi
> was an Imperial Court post prior to the Kamakura bakufu th=
at provided
> the same role as the bakufu's shugo (with shugo actually bein=
g brought
> about by the Kamakura bakufu to replace the kokushi). Is this c=
orrect?
> Generally, did the kokushi actually stay in the lands they were
>=
 responsible for, or were they like Governors and resided in the capital?
>=
 
> Thanks,
> Angus
